Regarding the large number of immune miners, the issue we face is as follows:
- We need the smoothing period of the prompt scores to be sufficiently long so that competitors can't get to the top by luck, and so that they're not incentivised to spam different hyperparameters for their models across a load of miners. Ideally it would be longer than it is currently, as we still see some 'hyper-parameter spamming'

- So as to not give new miners an unfair advantage over existing miners, we need to score them over the entire smoothing period, with bad scores for the period in which they weren't present (otherwise there would be an incentive to register many miners with wild models to try and fluke a few days at the top of the leaderboard when they're first registered)

- In order to give miners coming out of immunity a decent chance against existing miners, and so they're not de-registered immediately, the immune period has to be a comparable length to the smoothing period (currently the smoothing period is 10 days, and the immune period is 7 days, in an ideal world these time periods would match)

- The Bittensor elastic pricing for the registration fee is hardcoded to have an equilibrium level of around 20 miner registrations per day (ideally Bittensor could change this to be a variable parameter), which in our case of a 7 day immune period would lead to 140 immune miners, which is an undesirably large amount

- So we need to aim for fewer miner registrations, which currently the only lever we can pull to influence this is increasing the registration cost

If there was a way to further encourage or ensure each 'competitor' only had a few miners, that would help resolve the above issue. Currently the steep reward function does encourage this (as if your model is genuinely the best, then a single miner can be attributed a large portion of the rewards, without the need for having multiple miners), although steeper reward functions require longer smoothing, and hence also exacerbate the immunity problem. There was a mention on here of other subnets using sybil prevention mechanisms. What methods have they used? Also happy to hear any suggestions around the above problem

messages.content:
thanks for the question. 
1. You can track miner rewards and sells via their wallets on public dashboard, on many subnets miners sell 100% of emissions, on synth this is much lower. You can consider emissions as a cash cost on daily average price.
2. Eighteen percent of emissions accrue to Synth as revenue. You can verify this on the owner wallet in Taostats. There is only 1 tx which is a publicly announced OTC - with a long term lockup.

On revenue, we received a six figure payment from a client last month. Based on this first payment alone, and excluding the second client that is being finalized, we are already well above 2x monthly team and tech costs.

Our goal is to grow as fast as possible with revenues covering operating costs so we never need to sell any alpha on the market.

We are closing more enterprise clients and building new revenue lines. That includes agents, prop trading, deeper ecosystem integrations, and a broader set of predictions, especially in prediction markets. We cannot share every detail just yet but will keep you updated as continue growing synth as the predictive intelligence layer for finance and beyond.
so if you pay someone and they don't spend the money, it's no longer a cost?
and you are saying your owner alpha is revenue?

I am saying that if mining emission is considered cost, then 18% of owner emission should also be considered revenue. But another perspective is that the both the owner share and miner share are ownership value of the network. Only when it’s sold it has cash value. We are not naive in thinking the miners will lock up the miner share so our goal is to make sure that we have external revenue so that we don’t need to sell ownership.

For me what’s most important is that when you are operating 40 UIDs, your models are high-performant and consistently beats benchmark. At the end of the day, operating multiple UIDs is not going to yield higher reward if the models are not good. Our beta parameter controls the steepness of the rewards curve. Only when the model output is excellent when we can convince more users for Synth data, which drives the revenue and in turn alpha price. 
As Synth, We want to make sure both are true: 1. The subnet always welcome top model challengers 2. Top models are fairly rewarded, including both rewards in token and there is no unfair dereg.

Thank you for everyone's enthusiasm on  our upcoming HFT prompts. We would like to open up this discussion to our miners wrt one key design here. I'm reserving team's arguments for each options as to not to influence your perspectives. 

**🧮 Discussion: 1hr vs 24hr Scoring Structure**

We’re currently evaluating two potential approaches for how 1-hour and 24-hour prompts should contribute to miner scoring and rewards. Both structures have different implications for incentives, leaderboard behavior, and model design. We’d like to collect detailed reasoning and perspectives from miners, especially those consistently near the top of the leaderboard.

**Option 1: Combined Scoring**
All prompts (1hr and 24hr) contribute to a single smoothed score, which would determine rewards via the existing Softmax function. The weighting between timeframes would be adjusted so both 1hr and 24hr forecasts are represented fairly.

**Option 2: Separate Scoring**
Create two smoothed scores and leaderboards — one for 1hr and one for 24hr forecasts — and distribute rewards equally between them (for example, 50% to each). This could be done within our current scoring setup or through a Subnet Mechanism.

**Questions for Discussion**
1. Which approach do you believe would lead to higher model quality over time, and why?
2. How would each setup influence the type of models you build or maintain?
3. What potential unintended effects or edge cases do you see with either option?

We’re looking for **reasoned input **rather than simple votes, so please share your thought process and perspective.

In terms of incentives would the main different be that option 1)  you need to be good at both ? And option 2)  you can specialize?  Anecdotally on other subnets allowing specialization tends to lead to better outputs  so I would favor option 2.   Also I wouldn't call 1 min scale HFT.

I believe method 2 is better. There are differences between 1-hour and 24-hour forecasts. They involve different data selection and prediction methods. Therefore, scoring these separately can improve the quality of the models for those timeframes. For example, while some miners may score highly on 1-hour forecasts, others may score highly on 24-hour forecasts. Combining these two models creates the strongest prediction model.
In my opinion option 2 is better. To the above mentioned arguments I'd like to add that separate scoring will mean more stability and less potential manipulations/chaos with registrations.

Between the two options, I’m for separate scoring. One-hour and 24-hour forecasts are different animals. Splitting them gives clearer feedback, lets people specialize, and reduces weird incentives you get when everything’s blended.

I also tend to prefer separate scoring, as many people mentioned above, one-hour and 24-hour forecasts are different, some people are good at the former while others are good at the latter, let the professional miner take responsibility for what they are good at, which helps improve overall effectiveness. I hope miners can choose independently which forecasts to participate in.

All great inputs. thanks everyone!
It seems there’s strong support for Option 2, with many of you pointing out that separate scoring allows for model specialization and clearer feedback.

Now, I’d love to hear a counterpoint in favor of Option 1: combining the incentives for 24h and 1h predictions.
At the core, the question is: does Synth need miners to be good at both time horizons?
And if so, what’s the value in encouraging an all-encompassing model versus letting miners specialize, commercially or technically?
Would appreciate any thoughts that can help sharpen this trade-off.

First, combining the two scores doesn't tell you which part of your model performs better.
This is because there are differences in data and methodology between 1-hour and 24-hour forecasts.
This means speed of model development will be very slow.
However, if we manage everything separately, we can achieve continuous improvement with clear goals.
how can these two types of predictions be scored? are they weighted?

Here is my opinion:
Is simulating price of next hour and next 24 hour totally different? I think no.
They are in the similar context - simulation and prediction.
So I think those two simulation principles can be generalized into one, or even can be used to simulate path of any time zone. 
This is what math is for.
For example, analysis of quadratic equations and cubic equations seem to be completely different, but we can generalize them into one expression - analysis of n-order equations.
This is my technical view on all-encompassing model.
Commercially, if we have a generalized model, we can get more choices or opportunities of course, which is sure to lead more profit. 
For instance, we can simulate prices next any hours, and get more confirmative result that can make more confirmative profit. This can minimize the risk.

But personally, I want to see the separate scores too. Because that can help to generalize the model. The more data we get, the higher accuracy our model will have.
